author: sky.cactus
content: We mint in order to tax the entire system (though, there is definitely an argument that you are *actually* taxing holders) to pay for public goods (chain security).

author: sky.cactus
content: We burn in order to penalize people who incur costs on the system.

author: sky.cactus
content: It so happens that burning does end up "going to holders", but that isn't the *intent*.  The intent is to punish people that put stress on the system (use it) proportionate to the amount of stress they apply.  Complexity goes way up when you try to figure out who should receive the money paid, and it is much simpler to just burn it.

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially we picked the simplest economic design, which has a net effect of impacting holders both on the mint side and the burn side.  We leave it up to market participants (holders) to value that as they see fit, but our goal isn't to enrich them.  If the market values future ETH higher than today ETH, then that is an acceptable outcome, and the inverse outcome is also acceptable.  The long term valuation of ETH isn't a primary target.

author: jgm
content: A more general concern for me is not the absolutes but the relatives.  If a DeFi opportunity pops up that provides, say, 10% returns on ETH then although it has no impact on the yield that can be obtained from staking it does change the likelihood that an ETH holder will become (or continue to be) a staker.  Hence the general idea of minimum viable issuance is not easy to codify in the protocol.

author: sky.cactus
content: Agreed, but I believe that is why the system gives a higher yield the lower the amount staked gets.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is certainly possible that even on the low end the yield isn't high enough, though I am dubious about the claims that people will prefer DeFi yields (which are chalk full of massive black swan risks) over Ethereum yields (which is much more robust/sound of a system).

author: sky.cactus
content: DeFi yield chasers are gamblers/day traders, while ETH Stakers are more like long-term investors.

author: hack3r_0m
content:
hi guys, how does eip 1559 will affect smart contracts wallet like gnosis-safe which rely on gas price ?
for e.g: https://github.com/gnosis/safe-contracts/blob/main/contracts/GnosisSafe.sol#L207 (and many such lines which rely on gas price)

author: sky.cactus
content: It doesn't directly affect contract wallets, but it *does* affect meta-transaction providers.  Gnosis wallet is a contract wallet which has built-in support for meta-transactions IIUC, and it is the latter part that is impacted by 1559.

author: hack3r_0m
content: thanks, in what way it will impact meta-tx providers? i am not able find any related changes in openGSN or any other provider.

author: sky.cactus
content: It means they can likely get rid of or vastly simplify their gas price oracles.

content:
how excatly?
if i am not wrong, gasPrice was used in meta-tx for keeping track of total eth consumed. by simplyfying gas oracles you mean they can use baseFee for rough estimation?

author: sky.cactus
content: They can use `baseFee` to determine how much a transaction *should* have cost.
